â€‰ I just started this job. At will state. I sit at the door monitoring employees who enter and exit a large warehouse for theft of products. The warehouse is locked. It has 12 forklifts that travel the aisles at a fast rate of speed throughout the day. Since I am a contractor (security) who has worked Amazon and GNC in the past, I brought my own steel toe boots and hard hat. I was told do not wear them. Today, after one week, I was told I am not allowed to wear any hearing protection either. I can hear all the forklifts EASILY through foam earplugs and am worried about hearing loss at this point. The forklift path is 5 feet away for 10 hour days with continuous noise. Isn't it my right to protect my own hearing? The workers in the warehouse are allowed to listen to music as loud as they want so I do not see a difference. I could understand if I needed to hear a passing forklift but I am entirely stationary. Thoughts?

â€‰ Halfords beats expectations after cost savings and price rises Halfords has revealed stronger-than-expected profits for the past year, supported by cost savings and pricing measures. The motoring and cycling retailer said it saw underlying pre-tax profits rise by 6.4 per cent to Â£38.4m for the year to 28 March, having previously pointed to profits between Â£32m and Â£37m. Recently appointed boss Henry Birch said it reflected a "strong" performance from the business and showed it had made progress with its growth strategy. The company sought to reduce costs in order to cushion the impact of inflation. Halfords told shareholders that it saw around Â£33m in cost inflation over the year, partly driven by the increase in the minimum wage. It said it had offset this through cost savings worth around Â£35m. Total revenues rose by 0.1 per cent to Â£1.72bn for the year, with like-for-like growth of 2.5 per cent. The firm's autocentres business saw like-for-like growth of 3.7 per cent, while retail sales were up by 2.1 per cent. Babcock hails 'new era of defence' driven by rising global threats Babcock International has hailed a "new era for defence", with rising global threats prompting governments around the world to strengthen spending, especially on the burgeoning nuclear sector. The company generated an operating profit of Â£364m in the year to the end of March, 51 per cent higher than in the previous year, while revenues grew by 11 per cent to Â£4.8bn. It also said it was now expecting to meet its target underlying operating margin in the next financial year - one year earlier than it previously thought. Babcock maintains the UK's fleet of submarines, and also provides engineering support across the marine, nuclear, land and aviation sectors. Tritax Big Box to buy rival Warehouse in Â£485m deal Distribution infrastructure firm Tritax Big Box has agreed a Â£485.2m deal to buy a London-listed rival, fending off a competing bid by private equity giant Blackstone. Warehouse REIT (Real Estate Investment Trust) said bosses have recommended the proposed takeover, which values Warehouse - which owns a raft of distribution sites run by companies including Amazon - at 114.2p per share. It comes weeks after Warehouse originally agreed to be bought by US private equity firm Blackstone for Â£470m. The firms said the move would deliver Â£5.5m a year in immediate cost synergies due to larger economies of scale. â€‰ So, I tried a Gorilla Mind for the first time a while back (a few months ago), and I can honestly say it was a bad decision. Seemingly a terrible one. Since I first got my hands on Gorilla Mind, I became enamored with it. I'd seen advertising for it and heard good things about it from a friend of mine, so I decided to pick one up. Nearly every day past that fateful day, I've drank at least 5 Gorilla Minds a day, and it's been getting worse over time. At first, the caffeine made me feel jittery and anxious, but I've developed a tolerance. Now, I'm pretty much just drinking them because I can't stop. I don't need them for the energy when I go to the gym or anything, it's simply because they're irresistible to me. They're absolutely delicious and each time I crack a fresh one open, I get a rush. My attitude towards it is like that of a drug addict, and like them, I'm not sure I can stop. If I try to go more than a few hours without one I start experiencing withdrawals and it's fucking horrible. My anxiety shoots through the roof and my focus (and vision) gets clouded. Another issue is that Gorilla Mind is beginning to affect my behavior, and it's scary. Sometimes I mutter â€œGorilla Mindâ€ under my breath and I can't control it. Something that's also involuntary that I've been dealing with since my addiction began is increased irritability. I'm more angry and even little things can set me off. I sometimes undergo what I've come to deem â€œGorilla Mind rage.â€ What happens when I'm in this state is that I start making gorilla sounds and walk on all fours and become aggressive like I am a gorilla. Recently, it's been particularly bad. The worst case of this so far was when I was drinking a Gorilla Mind while driving to the gym a few weeks ago and someone behind me honked because I was driving a bit slow. This enraged me, so I stopped my car and got out. I ran over to this person's driver side window like a gorilla would and began screeching at them. I then punched their window while still screaming and shattered the glass, but I was able to get away before the cops arrived. I probably now have a warrant out for my arrest, so things just couldn't be worse. My friends and family are becoming concerned for my wellbeing, and suspect that I'm using substances. In reality, the only â€œsubstanceâ€ I'm addicted to is Gorilla Mind. However, I fear that it could be equally as bad as some hard drugs, given the dark path it's leading me down. I can also feel my cognitive abilities slowly declining, which may be more concerning than the anger issues it's causing me. As I said, I'll randomly mutter or otherwise say â€œGorilla Mindâ€ throughout the day, and it's very odd. For example, when I go to purchase Gorilla Minds at my local GNC, I get extremely excited and always whisper â€œGorilla Mindâ€ to myself as I wait for the cashier to ring them up. I can tell the workers think I'm crazy, but I keep going back just to satiate my addiction. It's not just this though, my mind is on the decline overall. I struggle to think very hard about things now, and of the few things that are on my mind, Gorilla Mind is the main one. As a result of this reduction in my critical and basic thinking skills, I'm more impulsive and increasingly focused on getting and drinking Gorilla Mind. It's all I really care about anymore. That's all for now, and if anyone, and I mean anyone, can relate to the story I've shared here, I'd appreciate hearing from you. I'd also appreciate advice on what I should do. Go to rehab? That's stupid thoughâ€¦ it's just an energy drink. I'd likely be laughed at. I don't know what's wrong with me. Or is there something seriously wrong instead with Gorilla Mind itself? I don't know, and I'm worried for my future. Anyway, thanks for reading if you made it this far. I'll end my unfortunate story with this final message: stay away from Gorilla Mind. I wouldn't recommend this product to anyone.

Tirumala: A car was completely destroyed in a fire near the GNC Toll Gate in Tirumala on Sunday evening, though the occupant, a devotee from Karnataka, escaped without injury. The incident caused a brief disruption in traffic flow near the busy entry point. The vehicle, owned by Sudarshan of Mulabagilu, was approaching the toll gate when it suddenly caught fire, with initial reports pointing to a possible technical fault. Firefighters and Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD) security personnel responded quickly, extinguishing the flames before they could spread. No injuries were reported. Police have launched an investigation to determine the precise cause of the blaze. Next Story More Stories

â€‰ I can get konjac noodles from the local International grocier for like $1.50 a pack - we have a large East Asian community in my city, so places with cheap konjac aren't that hard to find. Same with cheap fresh salmon, tuna, ginger slices, edamame, etc. If you live in the city, try searching Google Maps for places like that near you (if you live out in the boonies, good luck). I also got a GNC pro membership on sale for $30 for the year, to get the big sales and rebates on their protein. This way I can get the unflavored kind without having to order off Amazon and pay full price + shipping. Costco has chia seeds in bulk, $8 for 4 lbs, and that lasts over a month. They also carry sliced beef for hotpot (shabu shabu) at a reasonable price if you don't have an International grocier with a good butcher nearby. As others have said, tofu is always cheap and a good addition to your diet. Skip fake meat tofu and learn how to prepare the actual thing - you can make a cheap, good sauce for it with vinegar, soy sauce, corn starch, and some kind of sweetener. Chinese Cooking Demystified on YT has a TON of good recipies to try with it.

â€‰ I'm feeling basically the same. Except I'd argue for me it's more like, being a man gives me dysphoria, and I would rather be a woman, but I'm scared there are parts of being a woman that could also give me dysphoria. And there are things traditionally associated with men that I like too. It's hard for me to even really understand what it would be like to not have dysphoria, so I struggle to understand which of my feelings are dysphoria and which are manifestations of my many other brain problems. How much of my positive feelings around masculinity come from me convincing myself to be happy with what I have? How much of it is genuine? Whenever I'm in the most positive mindset it's usually when I'm looking at myself as nonbinary, and that being more femme is just a core part of how I want to present that nonbinary-ness. I want to be perceived, at least partially, the way women are perceived. I want people to think of me in a feminine context and treat me accordingly. That will take work, but there are plenty of nonbinary or even gnc cis women who can do it. I just need to follow what makes me happy. And on the alexythymia, I'm hoping that it'll become easier to identify my feelings when I start HRT. I want to see how it makes me feel mentally, and if it's as positive as I think it will be then I'll know this path is right for me.

â€‰ Supplements are NOT approved by the FDA before hitting store shelves. Unlike medications, companies don't have to prove they're safe or effective. âŒ Contamination with heavy metals âŒ Undeclared prescription drugs âŒ Wrong doses or fake ingredients âŒ Hidden stimulants or banned substances â—This isn't rare â€” it's happening right now in products you can buy at Walmart, Amazon, or GNC. OxyElite Pro â€“ Linked to liver failure and pulled after reports of death. Hydroxycut â€“ Caused seizures and liver damage, recalled in 2009. Ephedra (Ma Huang) â€“ Connected to over 100 deaths, finally banned in 2004. Kratom â€“ Still legal, despite causing addiction and fatal overdoses. ARIIX Rejuveniix â€“ Contained hidden pharmaceutical drugs. These were all sold legally until people got hurt. â—Just because it's on a store shelf doesn't mean it's safe. The FDA does not test or approve supplements before they're sold â€” and some have caused liver failure, heart attacks, and even death. Scary? It should be. Here's how to stay safe: Look for THIRD-PARTY TESTING. Since the FDA doesn't regulate supplements for safety, third-party testing is your only real way to know: âœ… What's actually in the bottle âœ… That it doesn't contain harmful contaminants âœ… That the dose matches the label âœ… That it's free from banned or hidden substances Trusted Third-Party Seals to Look For: NSF Certified for Sport USP Verified ConsumerLab Informed Choice If your supplement doesn't have any of these? That's a red flag âœ¨ Bottom Line: Not all supplements are bad â€” but many are untested, contaminated, or outright dangerous. Do your homework, ask questions, and only buy products that are third-party tested. Follow me for specific brand and supplement recs! #supplements #nutritionist #educateyourself #safesupplements #nutritionistapproved #makeamericahealthyagain #proteinpowder #vitaminsupplements

â€‰ At 15 I was exactly the same. I didn't like being called nor perceived as a girl, I liked boyish things but I didn't want to be trans nor a boy. At the time I just said to myself "whatever I'll figure it out later" and went for a gnc girl for a while. Eventually I realised I'm gender fluid - but **I** have moments in which I feel like I don't dislike being a girl and moments in which I wished I didn't have breast and so on. But that's me. From what you wrote your feelings seem constant. So 1. don't rush things, take your time. It's gonna all come together with time. 2. You might be some shade of NB (maybe demigender, or idk, pick your label), you might be simply gnc because you don't want to be like the other girls (for example ever since I was a kid I was scared of being sexualised. So I dressed up as a boy to be perceived as one because I did understand unconsciously that boys weren't), or you might remain unlabeled! "what gender are you?" "no." it frees your mind, sometimes, not to fit in any box. 3. explore yourself, try asking your friends or someone you feel safe with to try to call you with he/him, they/them or other sets of pronouns, try dressing differently, try another name, if you feel like yours doesn't fit you! Do it as long as you discover yourself fully and you feel comfortable. Don't push yourself over the limits just to test it. Be true to yourself and your feelings.

â€‰ Just wondering! I'm (22 NB) also an early intervention RBT at the moment as a preservice upper elementary teacher (3-6 all subjects, K-8 sciences and CS/tech). I don't lean SUPER hard into masculinity at the moment (because I'm, quite frankly, a bit scared to) and have been forced into femininity my entire life that feels like armor but also like a Halloween costume (protective, fun to wear occasionally, but all-around feels fake and performative on me). I definitely feel my gender identity is influenced by my neurodivergence. People usually incorrectly assume my gender identity as being a woman since I'm still building a more masculine wardrobe and I'm shorter, rounder, and have a larger chest. Working with younger kids, I find that I feel very alone since many of the people I'm surrounded by are mostly pretty feminine, nor do I feel very accepted with the guys I work with either. They just kind of lump me in with the women, which I sometimes find frustrating. I don't have a place where I feel I â€œfit inâ€ and often don't feel â€œallowedâ€ to be nonbinary in my profession working with kids who might be labeled as â€œtoo young to understand gender identity,â€ especially considering the current political climate, as well as my workplace's use of assessments and programming for clients that only use they/them as a plural pronoun. I don't  want to confuse them while they're still learning. I'm in a more conservative-leaning area. Many of my coworkers are queer, but no others are nonbinary or really GNC in any way. Just looking to feel less alone, vent a lil, maybe some advice, and wondering if there's any more of us out there!

â€‰ Classified in: Health Subject: PDT SADDLE BROOK, N.J., July 3, 2025 /PRNewswire/ -- Mira's Harvest, the Caribbean rooted herbal wellness brand behind the viral soursop bitters movement, has officially launched in 256 GNC stores across the United States and Puerto Rico, marking the brand's first major national retail rollout. The in-store debut features the brand's best selling Mango Soursop Bitters, a tropical spin on its signature bitter detox tonic that has taken TikTok by storm. Known for its bold taste and plant powered formula, the bitters support digestion, reduce bloating, and promote internal balance without synthetic ingredients. "This is more than a shelf placement, it's a moment," said founder Theo Edwards. "We took ancient Caribbean herbs that my grandmother used and built something modern, effective, and rooted in wisdom. To now see our bitters on GNC shelves is proof that people are ready for real healing." The Mango Soursop Bitters blend includes powerful ingredients like soursop leaf, sea moss, burdock root, ginger, and African mango. The flavor forward formula has quickly become a go to for gut health seekers and detox enthusiasts across TikTok, Amazon, and retail. With over 256 stores carrying the product and six figure monthly revenue across TikTok Shop, Amazon, and wholesale channels, Mira's Harvest is one of the only Caribbean founded wellness brands available in major U.S. retail. The launch signals a new era of culturally rooted herbal products entering the mainstream. Mira's Harvest Mango Soursop Bitters is now available in select GNC stores throughout the U.S. and Puerto Rico, and online at GNC.com. The company also plans to launch a 15 day herbal cleanse and soursop capsule line later this year. Media Contact: Angela Brooks 2015035854 [emailÂ protected] SOURCE Mira's Harvest News published on 3 july 2025 at 08:42 and distributed by

The Mango Soursop Bitters blend includes powerful ingredients like soursop leaf, sea moss, burdock root, ginger, and African mango. The flavor forward formula has quickly become a go to for gut health seekers and detox enthusiasts across TikTok, Amazon, and retail. With over 256 stores carrying the product and six figure monthly revenue across TikTok Shop, Amazon, and wholesale channels, Mira's Harvest is one of the only Caribbean founded wellness brands available in major U.S. retail. The launch signals a new era of culturally rooted herbal products entering the mainstream. Mira's Harvest Mango Soursop Bitters is now available in select GNC stores throughout the U.S. and Puerto Rico, and online at GNC.com. The company also plans to launch a 15 day herbal cleanse and soursop capsule line later this year. The in-store debut features the brand's best selling Mango Soursop Bitters, a tropical spin on its signature bitter detox tonic that has taken TikTok by storm. Known for its bold taste and plant powered formula, the bitters support digestion, reduce bloating, and promote internal balance without synthetic ingredients. "This is more than a shelf placement, it's a moment," said founder . "We took ancient Caribbean herbs that my grandmother used and built something modern, effective, and rooted in wisdom. To now see our bitters on GNC shelves is proof that people are ready for real healing." The Mango Soursop Bitters blend includes powerful ingredients like soursop leaf, sea moss, burdock root, ginger, and African mango. The flavor forward formula has quickly become a go to for gut health seekers and detox enthusiasts across TikTok, Amazon, and retail. With over 256 stores carrying the product and six figure monthly revenue across TikTok Shop, Amazon, and wholesale channels, Mira's Harvest is one of the only Caribbean founded wellness brands available in major U.S. retail. The launch signals a new era of culturally rooted herbal products entering the mainstream. Mira's Harvest Mango Soursop Bitters is now available in select GNC stores throughout the U.S. and Puerto Rico, and online at GNC.com. The company also plans to launch a 15 day herbal cleanse and soursop capsule line later this year.

"This is more than a shelf placement, it's a moment," said founder Theo Edwards. "We took ancient Caribbean herbs that my grandmother used and built something modern, effective, and rooted in wisdom. To now see our bitters on GNC shelves is proof that people are ready for real healing." The Mango Soursop Bitters blend includes powerful ingredients like soursop leaf, sea moss, burdock root, ginger, and African mango. The flavor forward formula has quickly become a go to for gut health seekers and detox enthusiasts across TikTok, Amazon, and retail. With over 256 stores carrying the product and six figure monthly revenue across TikTok Shop, Amazon, and wholesale channels, Mira's Harvest is one of the only Caribbean founded wellness brands available in major U.S. retail. The launch signals a new era of culturally rooted herbal products entering the mainstream. Mira's Harvest Mango Soursop Bitters is now available in select GNC stores throughout the U.S. and Puerto Rico, and online at GNC.com. The company also plans to launch a 15 day herbal cleanse and soursop capsule line later this year. â€‰ Photo Courtesy of: BetterAlt DOVER, Del., July 03, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- BetterAlt, a rising leader in Ayurvedic and science-backed wellness, has officially partnered with Sprouts Farmers Market to make its best-selling products available in 425 locations across the United States. The collaboration significantly expands BetterAlt's reach in physical retail, offering Sprouts customers convenient access to a curated line of natural supplements formulated for energy, performance, and holistic wellness. The initial rollout includes BetterAlt's most in-demand products: Himalayan Shilajit Resin Himalayan Shilajit Honey Sticks (Classic and Caramel) Himalayan Shilajit Gummies (Mango) Himalayan Shilajit Capsules Tongkat Ali Cordyceps Capsules Shilajit Sea Moss Capsules â€œPartnering with Sprouts is an exciting milestone for us,â€ said Akash Dhoot, cofounder at BetterAlt. â€œThey're known for putting quality and transparency first - values we care deeply about. Together, we're making it easier for people to bring time-tested, nature-based wellness into their daily lives.â€ Founded on the principles of Ayurveda and enhanced by modern science, BetterAlt's products are third-party lab tested at ISO-certified laboratories and formulated to support energy, stamina, cognitive performance, and daily vitality. The company has quickly gained momentum on digital platforms, including Amazon and TikTok, selling over 15 million servings of Himalayan Shilajit and 1.5 million customers within its first year of operations. The launch into Sprouts stores is part of BetterAlt's broader growth strategy to increase accessibility in high-traffic wellness retail channels while continuing to innovate in functional nutrition. With a focus on consumer trust and quality assurance, the brand is helping reshape how ancient remedies are adopted in modern lifestyles. About BetterAlt BetterAlt is a global health and wellness company blending traditional Ayurvedic wisdom with modern science to develop natural supplements for today's fast-paced world. Best known for its Himalayan Shilajit-based products, BetterAlt offers functional wellness in various consumer-friendly formatsâ€”from resins and capsules to gummies and honey sticks. The company has experienced rapid growth, achieving $100 million in annual revenue and 5x the growth rate. Recognized among the top 3 health brands on TikTok Shop, BetterAlt's products consistently rank #1 on Amazon in their categories and are also available through major retailers like GNC. Headquartered in the United States, the company currently serves markets across North America, Asia, and Europe. The company has quickly gained momentum on digital platforms, including Amazon and TikTok, selling over 15 million servings of Himalayan Shilajit and 1.5 million customers within its first year of operations. The launch into Sprouts stores is part of BetterAlt's broader growth strategy to increase accessibility in high-traffic wellness retail channels while continuing to innovate in functional nutrition. With a focus on consumer trust and quality assurance, the brand is helping reshape how ancient remedies are adopted in modern lifestyles. â€‰ Off Tirz after loosing 35lbs in 6 weeks. 220lbs to 185lbs wanted to see what the hype was with Reta even though I'm almost at my goal weight of 170 lbs. Just started Reta a few weeks ago current stack is Reta 1mg  1x week CCJ/ipa 500mcg daily before bed AOD 500mcg daily morning or before workout Tesofensine 500mcg tablet AM daily KLOW 4-6 mg 2-3 X daily MT2 250-500mcg weekly maintenance It's ALOT of pinning and rotating injection sites Running 20+ miles weekly Weight training 3-5 days Current diet is 10oz meals I buy 50 packs of 12oz food prep containers off Amazon. They're really small. Usually make 15 to 20 meals for the week for the wife and I. 1x eggs bacons sausage potatoes bell peppers 2x Brown rice, meat protein, broccoli, yams 2x protein BCAA 1x GNC mega men whole body multivitamins 1 gal water daily 4 LMNT packets or just pink salt and lemon.

â€‰ I completely agree with everyone's comments. When I got the new packaging, I thought it was just cosmetic. It turns out that it doesn't mix worth a dam, the sediment that is left is literally salt (I have chewed the leftover pieces and they are absolutely coarse salt), and the flavor is much worse. I can only tolerate chocolate flavored shakes, but I don't think the other flavors will be any different. I have had an Amazon subscription for isopure for a couple of years now, which I have since canceled. I'm returning my last container. My focus is carbohydrates. Isopure had a net zero carb for the chocolate flavor, which was fantastic. The closest match I have found is from GNC advanced muscle performance pure isolate chocolate lava cake. It has only two net carbs and only 15 more calories per serving, which is the best I can find so far. I did see isopure unflavored, which has zero carbs and lower calories. I haven't tried it yet. If I can't choke it down, I'm going to have to go with the pure isolate from GNC. I don't want to do that, because it's more calories, carbs, and is noticeably more expensive. Does anyone know how we can provide feedback directly to the company?

â€‰ I'll post a longer review on my 8 days in Mexico City but here are my overall thoughts: Culture/History: Amazing. So many things to see and do. If you are a history nerd you will get lost in all the knowledge there is. Do the pyramids, Palacio Nacional, Leon Trotsky House, etc. Food: Meh. The food was honestly mid asf. I've had better tacos in LA and Tijuana. I honestly can't say I had a good taco here. The pirata and gringas from Orinoco were really good. I also had some really good mole from Los Danzantes in Coyoacan. CDMX has cute cafes with good teas and pan dulce and sandwiches everywhere. I had good sandwiches (they call them baguettes) from Odette and Pasteleria Esperanza. Food is better in Tijuana and Oaxaca. People: Meh. I've met way friendlier people in TJ and Oaxaca. Here people are a little standoffish and on edge. I hate talking to Uber drivers but here trying to get an Uber driver to talk to you was like pulling teeth out of a dog. I did meet some nice people but they were all in Coyoacan. In Roma/Condesa/Zona Rosa/Reforma ppl were not really nice and I heard this from other people too. Most of the people that I vibed with were not from Mexico City. I met some cool people from Colombia, Brazil, and other parts of Mexico (Sinaloa, Jalisco) but didn't really make any connections with Chilangos. You could really feel the gringo fatigue. Safety: The city is surprisingly safe. I did not ever feel out of place or unsafe. I am not sure what everyone is so scared of. I used the metro, metrobus, and the combis to get around town. Never ever felt unsafe, I also never saw a pickpocket on the subway or in centro. Nightlife: Horrible. People just sit around and drink in small spaces. There is very little dancing. I came here expecting to dance but people just sit around tables with cubetas and talk or listen to someone sing karaoke. It was extremely underwhelming, I was expecting to stay out every night until 7am and I only went out once. One night I just decided to go back to sleep because it was so lame. Also the city shuts down pretty early by 10pm or sometimes earlier everything is closed. Also the drinks here are weak asf, this is something multiple people agreed with me on. I ordered a Long Island and it's literally supposed to have just a touch of cokeâ€¦why did the bartender pour half the bottle?? This is something I wanted to add: STARES: I have never been stared at so much in my life. At first it didn't annoy me because I know it's socially acceptable to stare in Mexico but by the end of my trip I was annoyed especially because I am not white, my family is from Mexico. I don't know what that was about at all and it actually pissed me off. I have also never experienced stares like this in TJ or Oaxaca. RACISM: No one wants to talk about how racist this city is. I was followed and racially profiled while buying laundry detergent at a Walmart in Condesa, I didn't even know that was supposed to be a rich neighborhood. It looked ghetto and rundown. I actually thought I was going to get mugged while walking to it but when I got inside I was the only brown person shopping in the store and the security guard decided to become my personal shopping assistantğŸ™„ I also think that's where the stares came from. I could sense that people could feel uncomfortable by my skin colorğŸ˜’ I could write more on this but whatever. They've never seen a rich successful brown person like me PRIDE: Pride was HORRIBLE. If you don't reserve a table or get a ticket to a bar/club weeks in advance you will be standing in a line outside of the club for hours....

â€‰ The Canadian senior men's football team will face Germany this fall to conclude the inaugural Gridiron Nations Championship. The contest will be played Nov. 16 in Bochum, Germany. Canada opened the GNC with a 56-0 win over Italy on April 19 in Cagliari, Sardinia. Max Nixon scored touchdowns on an interception return and blocked punt recovery for the Canadians while quarterback Michael O'Connor, a former CFL player with Calgary, Toronto and B.C., finished 11-of-14 passing for 138 yards with two touchdowns. Chris Merchant, who won a Vanier Cup with Western in 2017 and was the game MVP, completed 10-of-13 passes for 163 yards and a TD. The GNC winner will be determined by overall record, with the Canada-Germany contest potentially serving as the deciding game. If all three teams finished with 1-1 records, the tiebreaker will be point differential. Germany has enjoyed much football success in Europe. It claimed gold at the 2001, 2010 and 2014 IFAF European Championship while having finished second on three occasions. Canada's senior men's team has made just one appearance at the IFAF world championship, earning silver in 2011. The national junior program has won three straight world titles. â€œA championship like this is essential for the growth of the sport,â€ said Canada head coach Jesse Maddox. "We're excited to take on a top-tier program like Germany creating a new starting point and championship within a global competition. "The Nations Championship is exactly what international football needs â€” regular, meaningful games between national teams. It provides an opportunity for us to go for gold in 2025.â€ Germany and Italy will also compete in the 2025 IFAF European championship, which begins Oct. 25. The Germans will take on Austria while Italy faces Finland. This report by The Canadian Press was first published July 4, 2025. The Canadian Press

Building software for a rocket is an incredibly complex and critical endeavor! It requires extreme precision, reliability, and fault tolerance. Unlike a garage parking system, even a tiny bug can have catastrophic consequences. Blueprint for Rocket Software     Here's a blueprint for the software side of a rocket, outlining the key systems and considerations. 1. System Overview     The rocket software is the brain of the entire mission, responsible for controlling every aspect from liftoff to payload deployment and, for reusable rockets, landing. It must operate in real-time, handle vast amounts of sensor data, make critical decisions, and communicate flawlessly with ground control and various onboard systems. 2. Core Software Subsystems    2.1. Flight Control System (FCS)     Description: The heart of the rocket's navigation and guidance. This system ensures the rocket stays on its intended trajectory. Key Responsibilities:  Guidance: Determines the desired trajectory and current position/velocity. Calculates the necessary changes (delta-V) to reach the target. This often involves complex algorithms like Kalman filters for state estimation and optimal control theory. Navigation: Uses sensor data (IMUs, GPS, star trackers) to precisely determine the rocket's current position, velocity, and attitude. Control: Translates guidance commands into physical actuator movements (e.g., gimbaling engine nozzles, adjusting fin deflections). â€‰ Chicago, July 08, 2025 Â  Â  The global complementary and alternative medicine market was valued at US$ 193.36 billion in 2024 and is expected to reach US$ 1,282.70 billion by 2033, growing at aÂ CAGR of 23.56%. This growth is fueled by the rising prevalence of chronic diseases, increasing consumer awareness of natural and holistic therapies, and government initiatives promoting traditional medicine systems. Chronic conditions such as diabetes, arthritis, and cardiovascular diseases are driving demand for CAM therapies, which are often used as complementary treatments to alleviate symptoms and improve quality of life. For instance, acupuncture and herbal remedies are increasingly being adopted as non-invasive alternatives to conventional treatments. Explore Free Sample Pages Before Purchase â€“ Includes Visuals and Segment Insights: Consumer awareness is another critical driver, withÂ 40% of adultsÂ andÂ 12% of childrenÂ in the U.S. using some form of CAM. This reflects a growing shift toward natural and integrative healthcare solutions. Governments worldwide are also playing a pivotal role in promoting CAM. India'sÂ Ministry of Ayush, for example, has been instrumental in advancing Ayurveda, yoga, and naturopathy, while China has integrated Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) into its healthcare system. However, challenges such asÂ limited insurance coverage,Â regulatory hurdles, andÂ skepticism about efficacyÂ persist. Most CAM therapies are not covered by insurance, making them less accessible to lower-income populations. Despite these challenges, the CAM market presents significant opportunities for stakeholders, including pharmaceutical companies, healthcare providers, and investors. Regional Insights: A Global Perspective Europe: The Largest Market Europe dominates the complementary and alternative medicine market, accounting forÂ 34% of global revenue in 2024. Countries like the UK, Germany, and France are leading adopters of CAM therapies, with a strong focus on homeopathy, acupuncture, and osteopathy. In the UK alone, overÂ 40% of the populationÂ has used CAM therapies at some point, with annual spending exceedingÂ US$ 543.71 million. The region's growth is supported by a well-established infrastructure for CAM practices and a high level of consumer awareness. However, limited insurance coverage and regulatory inconsistencies remain significant challenges. For instance, while Germany has a robust framework for homeopathy, other countries lack standardized guidelines, creating barriers for market entry. Asia-Pacific: The Fastest Growing Region Asia-Pacific complementary and alternative medicine market is expected to grow at the highest CAGR during the forecast period, driven by its rich heritage of traditional medicine systems like Ayurveda, TCM, and naturopathy. The region also benefits from strong government support. For example, the Indian government has allocated significant funding to promote Ayurveda and yoga, while China has integrated TCM into its national healthcare system. â€‰ I'm really late to this but me and my bf are obsessed tbh. He was on and on about this and I was super against it because I thought it was expensive and stupid. He got the ribeye and brisket. I tried it and went fucking wild. I loved it so much I literally thought about it all day the next day at work, and ordered more. Then the new box came it felt like that SpongeBob episode where squidward didn't want to try the krabby patty and started obsessing, and SpongeBob caught him and he locked himself in the vault lol. The only thing that stops us from ordering more is the fact we can't afford it. And I hate ordering from websites / paying for shipping. I DO understand why the price is what it is now. Not because of just how good it is but like. . it's a fucking ribeye. I know there's a tj dillashaw version that just came out and for example it's a 20oz ribeyeâ€¦ like. . a 12oz ribeye where I'm at is around $16-20+ Let alone a 20oz ribeye, plus the cost and labor of it being sliced, cured, commercial packaging, websites, employees, etc. like it all actually makes sense when you look at it from that angle. I actually only found this post because I'm trying to find an easily accessible dupe lol. I'm looking into a dehydrator on prime day and the tj dillashaw brand ones because apparently they're on Amazon, and at some sprouts and gnc and again, I'm going for convenience. If I have to wait a week for them to arrive I also have to consider buying more than one because I won't want to order again for a while and shipping is like $6 + unless you're spending like $200. Which I am priced out of the free shipping market lol. When I get tipped well from a client I'd like to swing by sprouts or gnc or somewhere local and buy a bag to bring home, and treat me and my bf like you would by grabbing dinner or some wine for example, but the ordering online part makes that hard. Anyways. Definitely recommend x10000. They're meant to be refrigerated after opening since I saw someone said it's gonna go rancid. They're meant to be eaten in about a week but we did stretch one bag once to about 2 weeks as we went out of town and forgot about them, they seemed fine and we still enjoyed them. We've tried a few, and the best were the ribeye and brisket as well as the wagyu but that ones members only so you have to keep an eye out or join the email list and every once and a while they'll drop it for everyone for a day. The ribeye is special and a 10/10 but me and my boyfriend agreed the brisket for whatever reason is â€¦ almost exactly the same. It's maybe like 5% less good, if that, but I'd like $8/9 cheaper something like that. So we normally buy brisket now so we can save a little. Idk why it's so fucking good and similar to the ribeye but it is. The wagyu speaks for itself. they're all like crispy, but literally melt in your mouth. We have had a few other cuts and they were GOOD but wouldn't get again since we know how good these two are. The others weren't AS like melt in your mouth and had more. . I don't want to say chew but more â€¦ grit? Idk. Absolutely try
